question.name: Gender
question.text: Please select your gender.

question.name: Residence
question.text: Please provide your state (if in USA) or country (if outside USA)CR of residence.

question.name: Age
question.text: Please select your age category.

question.name: English Language Ability
question.text: Please select your level of English language ability.

question.name: Education Level
question.text: Please select your education level.

question.name: Study Areas
question.text: What were the primary areas of study (majors, research focuses, etc.)CR during your academic career? Please list all areas.

question.name: Systems Thinking Experience
question.text: Do you have any experience in Systems Thinking? If yes,CR where does this experience come from (classes, books, conferences, workCR experience, etc.)?

question.name: Computer Gaming
question.text: Please select your computer gaming background.

answerOptions.answerOption: Play computer games more than 5 hours a week
Play computer games between 1 and 5 hours a week
Play computer games between 15 minutes and 1 hour a week
Play computer games sometimes, but less than 15 minutes a week

question.name: Learning Style
question.text: Please select your preferred learning styles, if any. You may select more than one.

answerOptions.answerOption: Visual (spatial): You prefer using pictures, images, and spatial understanding
Aural (auditory / musical): You prefer using sound and music
Verbal (linguistic): You prefer using words, both in speech and writing
Physical (kinesthetic): You prefer using your body, hands and sense of touch
Logical (mathematical): You prefer using logic and reasoning
Social (interpersonal): You prefer to learn in groups or with other people
Solitary (intrapersonal): You prefer to work alone and use self-study

question.name: Occupational Area
question.text: Please describe your area(s) of expertise in your career.

question.name: Job Titles
question.text: Please provide your current and past position title(s) in your career, if anyCR (Ex: Elementary Teacher, Designer, Systems Engineer, Associate Professor, etc.)

question.name: Career Experience
question.text: How many years of professional work experience do you have, if any?

question.name: Tutorial
question.text: After the introduction and tutorial, do you feel likeCR you understand how to play the game?

question.name: Four Shapes
question.text: Did your changes work the way you expected them to? If not, please explain.

question.name: Four Shapes
question.text: Please describe how you approached this stage and what your strategy was.

question.name: Four Shapes
question.text: After observing all turns, you may have noticed that most of theCR shapes are often gone. Why?

answerOptions.answerOption: The shapes did not move enough

question.name: Four Shapes
question.text: What makes a shape divide into two?

question.name: Four Shapes
question.text: What does the rain do when the Growth variable is set to "Growth" (the default setting)?

answerOptions.answerOption: It increases the size of shapes, turns into red balls, and turns red balls into spikes
It increases the size of shapes only
It has other interrelated effects not stated here

question.name: Four Shapes
question.text: What would most likely happen to the overall system if the rain rate wereCR increased by a large amount but no other variables were changed?

answerOptions.answerOption: Shapes would shrink and possibly disappear
It depends on when the rain rate is increased

question.name: Four Shapes
question.text: What are the things that make the spinning shapes increase in size? Check all that apply.

answerOptions.answerOption: They automatically increase in size over time
They automatically increase in size while moving
Stealing or "pulling" size from other nearby shapes

question.name: Four Shapes
question.text: What happens when 2 red balls collide?

answerOptions.answerOption: The 2 balls disappear but 3 new balls are created nearby
The red balls bounce off of each other

question.name: Four Shapes
question.text: Is there a key factor limiting growth of the number of spinning shapes in this system?

answerOptions.answerOption: No, growth is not limited by anything
There are not enough red balls
The system starts with too few spinning shapes
The size of the play space

question.name: Four Shapes
question.text: Does this system remind you of any real life system?

question.name: Chaos
question.text: Did your changes work the way you expected them to? If not, please explain.

question.name: Chaos
question.text: Please describe how you approached this stage and what your strategy was.

question.name: Chaos
question.text: Would you say the system, without any of your changes, is stable or unstable?

question.name: Chaos
question.text: If a large shape, rapidly spinning left (counter-clockwise), wereCR introduced to the system, what do you think would happen to it overCR time?

answerOptions.answerOption: It would stay the same size

question.name: Chaos
question.text: What things in the game directly affect the red balls? Check all that apply

question.name: Chaos
question.text: What does the color of a spinning shape mean?

answerOptions.answerOption: It determines how fast a shape grows
It determines how fast a shape moves

question.name: Chaos
question.text: Which of the following sets of actions is most likely to gain your shapeCR the most levels the fastest?

answerOptions.answerOption: Double its maximum spin speed and change Paradigm to Competitive
Place it alone in a group of emerging red balls and change Paradigm to Independent
Double the maximum rain rate and place your shape alone near the top of the screen

question.name: Chaos
question.text: Which of the following would you include as part of the total "system" thatCR affects the game score? Check all that apply.

answerOptions.answerOption: The locations that the shapes start in
The number of corners the shapes have (triangle, square, etc.)
The weather patterns above the Arctic Circle
The time of day that you did the simulation
The personal biases of the simulation's designer

question.name: Chaos
question.text: Which would you say are the root causes of the fact that your shape will notCR gain levels in the final stage if you don't intervene? Check all that apply.

answerOptions.answerOption: There are too many shapes on the screen and they block your shape from rain and red balls
The shape is spinning in the wrong direction
The game designer's desire to challenge the player
The limits of the Java programming language used to create the program
The researcher's goal to improve complex problem solving skills globally

question.name: Chaos
question.text: Is there any reason you believe you did not do as well as you could have? Check all that apply.

answerOptions.answerOption: Actually I'm happy with my performance
I need more education or experience in solving systemic problems
The game was too short and I did not have enough time to learn how the systems worked
The game was too long and I became tired over time
I enjoyed the game but it took longer than I thought, and I did not allocate enough time
I was distracted often during gameplay
I did not understand how the game interface worked
I liked the gameplay but there were too many questions
I liked the questions but I did not like the gameplay
It was too hard to figure out how the systems worked

question.name: Chaos
question.text: In addition to the variables offered in the Change the System screenCR (Shape Type, Rain Rate, Paradigm, etc.), were there any others that you wouldCR have liked to have been able to change?

question.name: Chaos
question.text: How has your game play style changed over the course of the game?

question.name: Feedback
question.text: What are the things you found most difficult about this simulation?

question.name: Feedback
question.text: What are the things you found easiest about this simulation?

question.name: Feedback
question.text: Did any external factors affect your ability to perform well (disruptions,CR noisy environment, need for coffee, etc.)?

question.name: Feedback
question.text: Do you feel that your performance in the game reflected your abilityCR to think systemically? Why or why not?

question.name: Feedback
question.text: Did you understand the simulation tasks and your goals as a player? If not, please explain.

question.name: Feedback
question.text: If there are any other comments you would like to make, please enter them here.

question.name: Explore Multiple Perspectives
question.text: Please select the option that best describes your own behavior when solving complex problems.

answerOptions.answerOption: Approaches a problem from only one perspective
Explores other familiar perspectives when approaching problems
Begins to explore unfamiliar or contentious perspectives
Actively explores unfamiliar perspectives, but still tends to miss some non-obvious perspectives
Actively explores multiple, non-obvious perspectives, some of which might conflict with the thinker’s view

question.name: Consider the Wholes and Parts
question.text: Please select the option that best describes your own behavior when solving complex problems.

answerOptions.answerOption: Does not consider a problem holistically
Considers some holistic aspects of problems but misses others; tends to spend too much time in particular areas
Considers the problem holistically but tends to miss the importance of the parts; occasionally gets stuck in an event
Tends to consider the problem holistically and considers the importance of the parts in most cases
Considers both the “forest” and the “trees” keeping “one eye on each” consistently while approaching complex problems

question.name: Effectively Respond to Uncertainty and Ambiguity
question.text: Please select the option that best describes your own behavior when solving complex problems.

answerOptions.answerOption: Stops when faced with uncertainty or ambiguity
Difficulty making decisions during uncertain times or in ambiguous circumstances
Decisions made when faced with uncertainty are as often flawed as are appropriate
Decisions made when faced with uncertainty are often appropriate
Able to make sustainable system decisions despite uncertainties in their outcomes

question.name: Consider Issues Appropriately
question.text: Please select the option that best describes your own behavior when solving complex problems.

answerOptions.answerOption: Takes a reactionary approach to issues
Takes a reactionary approach to issues, but tends to realize that this approach has flaws
Sometimes takes appropriate time to allow issues and complexities to emerge; still reacts to issues and/or jumps to conclusions sometimes
Rarely jumps to conclusions when issues occur; often spends appropriate time to absorb complexity
Allows time for the complexity of a situation to sink in; rarely, if ever, jumps to conclusions; almost always considers issues appropriately

question.name: Use Mental Modeling and Abstraction
question.text: Please select the option that best describes your own behavior when solving complex problems.

answerOptions.answerOption: Does not recognize the value of mental modeling; intuitive models are highly inaccurate, overly simple, or overly complex
Recognizes the benefit of simplification through mental modeling; mental models may be inaccurate, overly simple, or overly complex
Recognizes that different mental models can influence perspectives and actions differently; able to simplify the problem through mental modeling with some accuracy and simplicity
Able to simplify the problem through mental modeling with increasingly accurate results using increasingly simpler models; recognizes that all models are flawed but some are useful
Devises the simplest mental model that accurately describes the system for a given purpose; recognizes that all models are flawed but some are useful

question.name: Recognize Systems
question.text: Please select the option that best describes your own behavior when solving complex problems.

answerOptions.answerOption: Does not recognize that a problem is systemic
Recognizes that the problem is systemic but cannot identify it
Recognizes that the problem is systemic and is able to identify associated behavior or system of interest in general terms
Recognizes that the problem is systemic and is able to identify associated behaviors or systems in concrete terms more than half of the time
Recognizes that the problem is systemic and is able to identify associated behaviors or systems in concrete terms almost always

question.name: Define and Maintain Boundaries
question.text: Please select the option that best describes your own behavior when solving complex problems.

answerOptions.answerOption: Unable to define the boundary of a problem
Able to create an initial mental model of the problem that contains some relevant elements. May contain extraneous elements or miss key elements
Able to maintain a problem boundary that evolves over time and context, and contains some relevant elements. May contain extraneous elements or miss key elements
Able to maintain a problem boundary that, over time and context, contains most of the relevant elements and minimizes extraneous elements
Able to maintain an accurate boundary of the problem that correctly changes over time and context with a high degree of quantitative accuracy

question.name: Differentiate and Quantify Elements
question.text: Please select the option that best describes your own behavior when solving complex problems.

answerOptions.answerOption: Unable to recognize that elements are different
Able to identify and differentiate between stocks and flows, as well as other types of variables and elements
Able to estimate properties of elements, such as the maximum quantity of a stock or the rate of a flow
Able to quantify properties of elements, such as the maximum quantity of a stock or the rate of a flow, accurately more than half of the time
Able to describe the properties of elements with a high degree of accuracy

question.name: Identify Relationships
question.text: Please select the option that best describes your own behavior when solving complex problems.

answerOptions.answerOption: Unable to recognize even those relationships that would be considered obvious by novice systems thinkers
Able to recognize relationships that are direct, linear, or close in space and time
Able to recognize some relationships even though they are indirect or distant in space or time
Able to recognize many relationships even though they are indirect or distant in space or time
Able to recognize the vast majority of relevant relationships, even obscure, meta-physical, non-obvious, or complex ones

question.name: Characterize Relationships
question.text: Please select the option that best describes your own behavior when solving complex problems.

answerOptions.answerOption: Unable to characterize the strength of a relationship
Unable to characterize the strength of a relationship with accuracy or consistency
Able to estimate the strength of a relationship with some consistency
Able to characterize relationships with increasing accuracy
Able to create highly accurate characterizations of relationships

question.name: Identify Feedback Loops
question.text: Please select the option that best describes your own behavior when solving complex problems.

answerOptions.answerOption: Able to recognize feedback loops that are linear, obvious, or close in space and/or time
Able to recognize some feedback loops even though they are indirect, non-obvious, or distant in space or time
Able to recognize many feedback loops even though they are indirect, non-obvious, or distant in space or time
Able to recognize the vast majority of relevant feedback loops

question.name: Characterize Feedback Loops
question.text: Please select the option that best describes your own behavior when solving complex problems.

answerOptions.answerOption: Unable to characterize the strength and properties of a feedback loops
Unable to characterize feedback loops with accuracy or consistency
Able to estimate the strength and properties of feedback loops with some consistency
Able to characterize feedback loops with accuracy more than half of the time
Able to create highly accurate characterizations of feedback loops

question.name: Describe Past System Behavior
question.text: Please select the option that best describes your own behavior when solving complex problems in a system.

answerOptions.answerOption: Able to describe past system behavior in general, conceptual terms
Able to describe past system behavior through estimation
Able to describe past system behavior quantitatively with some accuracy
Able to describe past system behavior with a high degree of accuracy

question.name: Predict Future System Behavior
question.text: Please select the option that best describes your own behavior when solving complex problems in a system.

answerOptions.answerOption: Able to predict future system behavior in general, conceptual terms over short timescales
Able to predict future system behavior in estimated terms over short timescales
Able to predict future system behavior with increasing levels of accuracy over longer timescales
Able to predict future behavior with a high degree of accuracy over a long timescale

question.name: Respond to Changes over Time
question.text: Please select the option that best describes your own behavior when solving complex problems in a system.

answerOptions.answerOption: Does not respond differently to changes in the system over time
Recognizes the need to respond differently over time
Responds to changes over time in ways that are less often effective than not
Responds to changes over time in ways that are more often effective than not
Consistently responds to changes over time in highly effective ways

question.name: Use Leverage Points to Product Effects
question.text: Please select the option that best describes your own behavior when solving complex problems in a system.

answerOptions.answerOption: Does not recognize leverage points that allow for significant changes to be made in a system
Recognizes obvious or lower strength leverage points, but often pushes them in the wrong direction
Recognizes some high strength leverage points, and usually pushes them in the right direction
Recognizes most low and high strength leverage points, understands their differences, and uses them effectively most of the time
Recognizes points of high leverage in a system. Consistently uses those leverage points to influence system behavior in desired ways
